results.title: Die Flambierte frau = A Woman in flames
results.brief_description:
A raw analysis of class, gender and sex, ‘Women in Flames’ centres on Eva, who one day, without warning, walks out of her stultifying middle-class marriage and into the world of high-class prostitution. Soon she begins an intense relationship with Chris, a fellow prostitute. They move in together but tensions emerge as Eva embraces her sexual freedom and sheds her middle-class moral scruples and Chris’s possessive instincts surface. Set almost entirely in fashionable interiors, stylishly photographed, and with music by Peer Raben the film begs comparison with Fassbinder’s work. Yet Van Ackeren’s film lacks Fassbinder’s assured hand. Cool and distanced, his study of a middle and upper class world ruled by money, power, and sex - where the unexpected and bizarre lie just beneath the tranquil surface, hovers uncertainly between voyeurism and social criticism.

Credits: Director, Robert van Ackeren ; writers, Robert van Ackeren, Catherina Zwerenz ; photography, Jurgen Jurges ; editing, Tanja Schmidbauer ; music, Peer Raben.
Cast: Gudrun Landgrebe, Mathieu Carriere, Hanns Zischler, Gabriele Lafari, Matthias Fuchs.

results.title: Die Deutschen luftwaffe. No. 6. Bombers & bomber ops 1942-1945
results.creator_credit: Mike Croker, Mickey Shephard and VAF Productions
results.brief_description: This documentary video contains some rare archival footage of the German Luftwaffe carrying out some of their bombing operations during the years 1942-1945 of World War II including photo-intelligence surveillance, aerial bombings, strikes on allied convoys with anti-ship missiles and night bomber raids against the British. At one stage during 1942, the Luftwaffe were capable of launching up to 1000 sorties per day. However by 1944 due to the growing effectiveness of Allied air power, the Luftwaffe bombing force began to decline, until Germany’s eventual surrender in May 1945. Aeroplane enthusiasts, and particularly those into war planes, will enjoy this documentary for its informative and historical visuals and its coverage of the various bombers used by the Luftwaffe, including the Junkers Ju-88 and Ju-188, the Dornier 217 series and the Heinkel He-111 and He-177, as well as flying boats and float planes operating from the Mediterranean through to the Arctic Ocean (in rare colour footage). Narrated by Brian Matthews.

results.title: Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
results.brief_description: While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Lotte Reiniger’s The Adventures of Prince Achmed precedes the Disney film by over a decade.

constellations_primary.name: Shadowplay and spookiness
constellations_primary.description: Silhouettes and shadows scare up some of the most sinister creatures in cinema and videogames.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_other.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

constellations_other.name: Storytelling through shadow play
constellations_other.description: Shadow play has brought stories to life for thousands of years and is still used today.

results.title_for_label: Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
results.description:
You may not have heard of German animator Lotte Reiniger. She turned her home into a DIY animation studio and pioneered animating silhouettes by shooting homemade puppets frame-by-frame against sheets of lead.

Later she used layers of glass to create depth, devising the first multiplane camera, which she used to create the first colour animated feature film, The Adventures of Prince Achmed (1926). While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Reiniger’s fairytale precedes the Disney film by over a decade. With more than 60 animated films to her name, Lotte Reiniger is a true hero of animation.
description_for_label:
You may not have heard of German animator Lotte Reiniger. She turned her home into a DIY animation studio and pioneered animating silhouettes by shooting homemade puppets frame-by-frame against sheets of lead.

Later she used layers of glass to create depth, devising the first multiplane camera, which she used to create the first colour animated feature film, The Adventures of Prince Achmed (1926). While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Reiniger’s fairytale precedes the Disney film by over a decade. With more than 60 animated films to her name, Lotte Reiniger is a true hero of animation.

results.title: Didgeridoo in Deutschland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Take an Aboriginal musician and an Australian composer … put them in the middle of Europe and what have you got? If the composer is George Dreyfus, the musician is Richard Walley, poet and exponent of the didgeridoo, and the European country is Germany, you get a fascinating look at two individuals whose people have been persecuted but whose vastly different cultures can come together in a totally satisfying work. Made with the assistance of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

results.title: Did You Used to Be R. D. Laing?
results.creator_credit: Andrew Feldmar, Tom Shandel, Kirk Tongas and Third Mind Productions
results.brief_description: Scottish psychiatrist, R.D. Laing, who died in 1989 shortly after this film was made, gained a reputation for his radical objection to conventional psychiatry. He opened the discipline to question in his books, “The Divided Self” and “Politics of Experience”. This video is a compilation of a series of public lectures and private conversations made by Laing shortly after his sixtieth birthday. He is revealed to be a charismatic and consummate storyteller who draws on his thirty-five years of pondering the fundamental issues of living, loving, suffering and healing.

results.title: Did It Again – Kylie Minogue
results.credit_line: ℗ 1997 Mushroom Records Pty. Ltd. (Seaman / Minogue / Anderson)
results.brief_description: For years, Kylie Minogue had been trying to break out of the boxes the press was determined to put her in: the pop star, bad girl, icon. In Did It Again, she confronted and combated each version of herself in a scenario inspired by The Usual Suspects (1995).

constellations_primary.name: Kylie to Lucy
constellations_primary.description: 'Did It Again' started the conversation about Kylie Minogue being more than just a pop star, it started to cement her status as one of the most important audio and visual artists of her time, but the video had an unlikely inspiration.

results.description: For years, Kylie Minogue had been trying to break out of the boxes the press were determined to put her into: Kylie the pop star, Kylie the bad girl, Kyle the icon. In the music video for ‘Did It Again’, she got to confront and combat each version of herself in a scenario inspired by The Usual Suspects. One of her most enduring hits, the video also cemented her status as a boundary-pushing visual artist.
description_for_label: For years, Kylie Minogue had been trying to break out of the boxes the press were determined to put her into: Kylie the pop star, Kylie the bad girl, Kyle the icon. In the music video for ‘Did It Again’, she got to confront and combat each version of herself in a scenario inspired by The Usual Suspects. One of her most enduring hits, the video also cemented her status as a boundary-pushing visual artist.

results.title: Did Darwin get it wrong?
results.creator_credit: Alec Nisbett and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Examines the Darwinian theory against the search for a new evolutionary theory. It asks molecular biologists whether DNA can really change that quickly. The answers are surprising.

results.title: Dickie bird: a bird's eye view of cricket
results.creator_credit: On the Box Productions, Video Collection International, Brian Klein and Norman Giller
results.brief_description: It is rare in a sport such as cricket that an umpire should have as much of a reputation and following as the players over which he adjudicates. Umpire Dickie Bird is a prime example of this exception to the rule. In this video he reflects on his most enjoyable moments from the game, reflecting on some of the greatest performances and players he’s seen, and culminates in Dickie donning the cricket whites to face one of the fastest West Indian bowlers ever.
results.title_for_label: Dickie bird: a bird’s eye view of cricket
results.creator_credit_for_label: On the Box Productions, Video Collection International, Brian Klein and Norman Giller

results.title: Dick Whittington and his cat
results.creator_credit: Sterling Educational Films and Tad Wilkosh
results.brief_description: Set in the Middle Ages using puppet animation to tell the story of the boy whose affection for a stray cat leads to wealth and fame, showing that kindness and goodness prevail. Narrated by Stanley Jackson. Written by Israel M. Berman.
